title: Will the median price of a house in New Zealand exceed NZ$870,000 in December 2021, according to REINZ?
preds:
Nov 925k
Expectation is that prices will continue to increase but more moderately.  It is summer in NZ so prime house buying season.
We have passed the threshold for this question, and a reasonable reduction is needed to go below the level, so we are very unlikely to not pass
I have to keep a 1pc chance for anything weird happening
Somehow I missed the Nov report until now.

$925k is a lot of money for the average small, poorly insulated, wooden, borer riddled, tin roofed, crappy old kiwi house.  All industry forecasts are suggesting a cooling of the market for next year but that is a big jump to go backwards now

Expecting November to be higher and then a drop for December - anecdotal evidence of a change in buying behaviour, more sellers than buyers, auctions on higher value housing closing without a bid - unheard of a month ago.
Holding 85% for now, will reassess after Nov data
Room for the impacts of previous comments to take hold

Median prices for residential property across New Zealand increased by 23.4% to $895,000 in October 2021 compared to $725,000 in October 2020. Ten out of 16 regions reached median price records, and one had an equal price record — the most since March 2021. The number of price records is above average for an October month, reflecting a firm market reinforced by continued demand.  https://www.reinz.co.nz/Media/Default/Statistic%20Documents/2021/Residential/October/REINZ%20Monthly%20Property%20Report%20-%20October%202021.pdf page 5

October is 895k.  Big jump month on month as expected with NZ coming out of restrictions a bit. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1347036
Also, forgot it is spring down there, so busy house hunting time, which will add pressure to prices.
No indications that this average will do down.  even excluding Auckland the house prices are at a record high. Look for Nov numbers around 10 Dec

Dropping slightly.
https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/business/454741/housing-prices-pose-risk-to-new-zealand-s-financial-stability-rbnz-governor-says
Reserve bank forecasting a drop but I suspect that they are referring to a multi-year rather than 2 month time scale

Sept 795k
This is a large drop compared to Aug,  it still a significant jump since last year.
It’s a bit confusing, but if I read the report right, the Sept numbers were affected by Auckland being in lockdown.  Trends are up nationally and quite sharply.  So if Auckland lockdown is the biggest impact in the sept reduction (as house prices in Auckland are higher than the rest of the country) then we might see a big jump in Oct back to Aug plus any increase in Auckland prices which would take us right to the question threshold.  Maintaining my forecast pending Oct data.   Expect publication around 12 Nov.

Did Reserve Bank of New Zealand's rate rise have an instant effect on housing prices? Probably not. Decline in price is likely a combination of Covid and inflation, but I am anticipating the rate rise, and what's looking like more inflationary pressure to come this year, will keep this number below $870k.

Thanks to great comments by @GMR and @oracle100. I think Delta and its attendant restrictions are going to keep the housing market from continuing its growth for a while and may cause this question to resolve to no.

Was going to increase but have talked mysef into holding my forecast as I further ponder Auckland vaccinating themselves into lvl2 by the end of November and the possibility of huge housing demand and sales. How would I sell my house in December 2020 as the market opens up again? by a set price and it is first in first served or go for a private treaty so people put in their best offer straight up, or at auction? Some happen immediately and some complete their sale a set date some time in the future, all could impact on December house values. Another big thing to consider: when does the sale price come into the report? when it goes unconditional or when it is settled? If it is at settlement then presumably even if Auckland opens up in December and a sales boom follows the sales won't be completed until January or later?
What do you think @oracle100 ?

Siding with the median-ish for now. The next several months is cooling down in the Northern Hemisphere but in the Southern, it's heating up. It seems based on US data, house prices and frequency of sales tend to increase during the summer so I do expect the trend to continue. This is consistent with the overall trend up if you graph the data points of the last 10 months or so of data that's available.
$795k for Oct. Coming off the peak?

Dropped again due to the impact of the covid lockdown in Auckland and now Waikato. There will be a spring back when NZ opens up again but there was quite a suppression in the median price this month - back down to 795 in the REINZ data that this question will be judged on. THe REINZ data is in contrast to other data (that I can't find again now) that put it up to closer to the target. 
Further the researve bank has finally increased the official cash rate though they still expect inflation to go up to 4% in the short term and then drop to 2 in the medium term (they don't forecast with probabilities though)
https://www.rbnz.govt.nz/news/2021/10/monetary-stimulus-further-reduced-official-cash-rate-raised-to-050-percent#:~:text=Monetary%20Stimulus%20Further%20Reduced%20%2D%20Official,Reserve%20Bank%20of%20New%20Zealand

Shift down on news of the NZCB raising interest rates.  The prices are likely to continue to be driven upwards as a result of the additional inflationary factors, but will stay down here until the next report.  1. https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-business-auckland-new-zealand-economy-16204c2fe4bfdd5f5f0863fcd720d097
August was 850k. Trend looks up, so going for a yes as we still have 6 months to publish.

So, the median price is already at $850,000 in August 2021.    For it to exceed 870K, a 2.5% increase in price is needed; for a comparison the price increase from October 2020 to November 2020 was 3.3%.
https://reinz.co.nz/Media/Default/Statistic%20Documents/2020/November/REINZ%20Monthly%20Property%20Report%20-%20November%202020.pdf [page 4] Hence, considering the price trend, and the madness (FOMO: fear of missing out) in housing market in NZ (for example look at the following article.) 
"Desperation among homebuyers is pushing New Zealand house prices to record highs, overpowering the government's efforts to rein in the red-hot market and putting in jeopardy a key policy promise by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern."
"The new owners didn't step foot inside before purchasing it... even we could not enter," said Ben Atwill of real estate group Ray White, which made the sale. "From what I am seeing, there is no stopping the premium dollars from coming through."
https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/cooling-measures-doing-little-slow-new-zealands-housing-boom-2021-08-06/  => it's bound to happen (I'm guessing we'll see even 900K)
The government's policies such as applying new taxes for property investors and putting checks on "flipping" activity proves not effective.  One approach to put a break could be to raise interbank interest rate; this is being done slowly, as otherwise it may break the bubble, instead of cooling the market down. 
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/IR3TIB01NZM156N
The rate is bellow %0.5 since May 2020 (after a sharp decline in a couple of months; e.g., it was at %1.27 in January 2020)

seems to be a question of timing; I expect prices to rise slightly above NZ$ 870k, then fall; simply because of continuation of trend, because the fourth C19 wave, crypto-bull-run and next round of stimuli are likely (0.85) to happen in Q4 2021 and contribute to rise in house prices. I expect they will start to decrease in Q1/Q2 of 2022, jointly with global market tretracements.
I had thought things might be leveling off, but yikes! $850k for Aug. Where does this end?

I don't like jumping from 55 to 85 but the recent report puts the median half way there and there is already an expectation that following the Auckland lockdown there will be a big jump in demand as people rush to buy/sell before the next one. Although this is expected to be followed by a drop as lending rules bite which stops me going higher.

If the July's 1.3% price increase persists then we're at 880K, and COVID lockdown lifting should drive home prices. However I assume winter is slower for home sales. Dropping this for now assuming winter will be slow.

On the recent trends alone this is quite tricky to pick, with five months of pretty stable median price (825, 805, 818, 815, 826 March-July incl.) so maybe the heat is off just a bit. But it was sky-rocketing just before that! I'm definitely not a house price junky, so know very little about what might influence things but this article (https://www.stuff.co.nz/life-style/homed/real-estate/125743196/why-house-prices-have-not-stopped-rising) suggests perhaps a few factors that could be helping to slow things. I notice that last year the price really climbed immediately after lockdown (from May 2020)... maybe the same will happen again!
Several regions have had a fall in month to month average price in the last month.  Any wider slow down will make this overall average target hard to reach.

https://www.corelogic.co.nz/news/property-market-slowdown-continued-august-covid-resurgence-could-cause-temporary-reversal-0#.YS7KS44zaUk
Tightest restrictions so far on loan-to-deposit ratios and threat of increasing interest rates should continue the cooling trend but the current lockdown may provide a temporary boost in Sept/Oct
Expecting another low month in the August in the upcoming REINZ report

On the other hand, housing inventory is at its lowest level ever.
"The total number of properties available for sale in New Zealand decreased by 34.8% in July to 12,684 down from 19,441 in July 2020 – 6,757 fewer properties compared to 12 months ago. This is the lowest level of inventory we’ve ever seen in New Zealand (surpassing the previous record low set in December 2020 with 12,932)."
https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5ce1fd700bf20400017d3a30/t/6114301bc89bd902013024ed/1628713030425/REINZ+Monthly+Property+Report+-+July+2021.pdf

It's "up to a record $826,000 in July 2021." It was $820k in June. There are indications that the index may be slowing down. 5 months remaining in the forecast. If the median price grew at $6k/month, $87k would not be reached. 
month, median price
Dec, $749k
Jan, $730k
Feb, $780k
March, $826k
April, $810k
May, $820k
June, $820k
July, $826k
$16k growth in 3 months, or 5.3k/month. Flat over 4 months. Price growth seems to have slowed.
I think my previous forecast (80% yes) was wrong.

$870,000 represents a 5% increase on July prices. Supply remains constrained, interest rates low but inward migration has slowed to a trickle and the course of the pandemic over the next 4 months could take some of the heat out of the market.  I am therefore starting this forecast on the low side with the expectation it will move upwards over time.

This forecast is based on:
REINZ's Prices index in July,Aug 2021 show a higher indications. 2-N.Z has a strong labour market and income opportunities, and interest rates remain low, so that is enabling the market to keep going.
https://i.stuff.co.nz/life-style/homed/real-estate/125967572/no-winter-slowdown-for-auckland-market
3-Many Houses has been sold at $2M.

Has been no change since March. Although June to Aug is normally the period where nobody puts their house on the market and their are still people wanting to buy. Expect new houses to come on the market soon and then we will see what a pent up demand might do. I am holding low for now. Almost want to drop a bit.

https://www.reinz.co.nz/Media/Default/Statistic%20Documents/2021/Residential/July/REINZ%20Residential%20Press%20Release%20-%20July%202021.pdf
https://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/BU2108/S00233/reinz-july-data-new-zealand-reaches-new-record-median-house-price-rate-of-growth-shows-signs-of-easing.htm
signs of easing but predictions are that it will still take a year or 2 to slow down.

$ 820k in June, with only + 0.3% Month/Month: https://www.blog.reinz.co.nz/s/REINZ-Monthly-Property-Report-June-2021-v2.pdf
With delta-strain rising, slight downward correction
rising number of covid cases (delta variant) might foreshadow another wave with severe lockdowns, with ensuing market correction
Housing is crazy. I will take the over.

If you go to https://www.interest.co.nz/charts/real-estate/median-price-reinz and set a breakpoint in the drop down list's change function, NZ median house price data are in this: data_response[79390].csv_data[0].map(xs => xs[1]).join(',') The past couple of years are exceptional; at that rate NZ median house price will be over $900,000.

" 'The New Zealand housing market has become the least affordable in the OECD. Taking action is in everyone’s interests as continuing to allow unsustainable house price growth could lead to a negative hit to the whole economy,' [NZ Finance Minister Grant] Robertson said."
https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/300259371/housing-changes-kick-in-from-this-weekend-as-government-unveils-major-policy Probably a return to a five-year-growth path of +9.3% p.a. or lower in H2 2021 with immediate effect will be observed due to political interventions and stricter criteria for the mortgage/financing business amid overheating fears of the Reserve Bank. The most recent price increases are mostly based on very few transactions in the Auckland and similar regions caused by speculative investment, while first home buyers are increasingly excluded from the market. Treasury is already projecting a halt in the house flipping business model ("Median days to sell" halved year-over-year in May 2021 to ~30 days). Supply side issues (low production of new houses) will remain a long-term support and demand in growing urban areas of NZ or other factors ( https://www.eiu.com/n/campaigns/global-liveability-index-2021/ )  likewise, which will prevent the market from crashing.

With the reasoning of https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1303746, I think the Government will aim to solidify price level and slow its growth to a trickle in order to avert a bubble burst. Most years do not have bursting housing bubbles (outside view), and (inside view) printing presses are likely to stay on until COVID can either be dealt with or habituation sets in. I think either will not happen till the end of the year. If the past can be any indicator for the future: $730,300 in January 2021 - up from $612,000 + 19.3% year-on-year (1)
$780,000 in February 2021 - up from $635,000 + 22.8% year-on-year (2)
$826,300 in March 2021- up from $665,000 + 24.3% year-on-year (3)
$810,000 in April 2021 - up from $680,000 + 19.1% year-on-year (4)
$820,000 in May 2021 - up from $620,000 + 32.3% year-on-year (5) Growthrate in % month/month slowed (+7; +6; -2; +1) and only +6% are neccesary from level of May 2021.  (1) page 3 https://www.reinz.co.nz/Media/Default/Statistic%20Documents/2021/Residential/January/REINZ%20Monthly%20Property%20Report%20-%20January%202021.pdf
(2) page 3 https://www.reinz.co.nz/Media/Default/Statistic%20Documents/2021/Residential/February/REINZ%20Monthly%20Property%20Report%20-%20February%202021.pdf
(3) page 3 https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5ce1fd700bf20400017d3a30/t/60777ec3bc2c737f0cdaafae/1618444011978/REINZ+Monthly+Property+Report+-+March+2021.pdf
(4) page 3 https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5ce1fd700bf20400017d3a30/t/609c4eb73fc8f9142091b468/1620856545962/REINZ+Monthly+Property+Report+-+April+2021.pdf
(5) page 3 https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5ce1fd700bf20400017d3a30/t/60c7cfb63fd8004686a2308a/1623707617072/REINZ+Monthly+Property+Report+-+May+2021.pdf
who wants to live in New Zealand ?

Pretty good rationale below  on NZ situation by @oracle100. The links have all the detail. 
Recent law changes have a long implementation time and interest rate rises are likely (0.25 to possibly 1.75%) but only over a 4 year time period. Unlikely that any govt changes will impact on demand in the time period of the question. Winter is a period of low numbers of houses for sale but this doesn't mean low prices. However recent data (reinz reports) have shown increases from Aug to Dec of 8% in 2019 and 10% in 2020.

For:
lack of housing stock, building consents slow, prices for building keep going up due to pressure on materials and labour - can't get materials and labour from overseas
people returning from o/s due to covid
people unable to travel putting their money into houses
low interest rates meaning large mortgages are more affordable.
great capital gains for investors. against:
Govt has said they will try to slow housing market using a series of tools, first of which is not allowing investors to offset interest against income. 
banks have raised longer term (5 yr) interest rates signaling they think interest rates will go up.
prices are totally unaffordable! median salary in NZ is $53k. double income no kids would have $110k/y and to purchase house of $820k is over 7x yearly salary - Banks used to recommend mortgage not to exceed 3-4x annual salary! https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/money/125581557/westpac-does-not-expect-house-prices-to-drop-until-late-2022
https://www.stuff.co.nz/life-style/homed/real-estate/125630521/rise-of-1m-mortgages-sparks-interest-rate-warning
https://www.reinz.co.nz/residential-property-data-gallery
https://www.reinz.co.nz/Media/Default/Statistic%20Documents/2021/Residential/May/REINZ%20Residential%20Press%20Release%20-%20May%202021.pdf
https://www.interest.co.nz/property/111131/average-auction-sales-rate-has-increased-despite-onset-winter
https://www.interest.co.nz/property/111123/listing-numbers-suggest-housing-market-activity-may-be-heading-back-pre-covid-levels
https://www.interest.co.nz/property/111112/bdo-tax-specialists-say-new-tax-rules-around-residential-property-investment-could
https://www.interest.co.nz/property/111092/average-value-all-new-zealand-homes-now-906532
https://thespinoff.co.nz/business/02-06-2021/weve-stopped-believing-what-they-say-about-house-prices/
https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/125190227/budget-2021-sharp-house-price-adjustment-coming-says-finance-minister
https://www.newsroom.co.nz/budget-2021-house-prices-forecast-to-plateau
https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/nz-kills-tax-loophole-on-property-to-slow-soaring-house-prices-20210323-p57d9s.html

Just looking at the housing price trend, the answer should be a clear yes. However, the real question is if we are going to the burst of housing prices in NZ. In an interview in about 4 years ago https://www.rnz.co.nz/national/programmes/sunday/audio/201845436/steve-keen-the-coming-crash the economist Steve Keen predicted that there'll be a a recession in NZ in about 2 years time. So, I'd say there is a possibility here.  On the other hand, with Covid19, and stimulus packages that the government spends, re-opening of the economy which boosts the tourism in NZ the probability of a recession in the next 6 months is not high - I assign 1:2 (burst : not burst)
Furthermore, according to investment manager Brian Gaynor in 2012, a 10% drop in house prices would wipe out $60 billion of New Zealanders' personal wealth; that's a huge amount, especially considering that NZ's GDP in 2019 was about 207 BUSD.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_property_bubble My guess is the government tries to contain the situation and take measures to cool the market down. If that will be a success, we have to see.
